content.caption: Tally marks – one of the earliest counting methods

content.text: Humans began with simple counting using tally marks. Over time, different civilizations developed number systems to represent quantities and perform calculations.
These systems evolved to support trade, astronomy, engineering, and science.

content.caption: Roman numerals – useful but hard for complex calculations

content.text: The Roman numeral system uses letters (I, V, X, L, C, D, M). While it served well for labeling and simple arithmetic, it lacks place value and zero, making complex calculations difficult.

content.caption: Place value system – foundation of modern arithmetic

content.text: The decimal (base-10) system with place value and the digit zero transformed mathematics. Each position represents a power of 10, making addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division systematic and efficient.
